Lara invited you to the mall with Marcie and Martin! You've definitely been accepted by these new kids. Maybe they'll be able to help you.[/p] [p]All you have to do is find a way to get to the mall without being fried by the sun.[/p]

[p]“What do you mean?” you demand. “All I want to do is return to the crypt!”[/p] [p]“There's only one way back there,” the blue head says.[/p] [p]“And it's extremely dangerous,” the red head adds. The blue head nods in agreement.[/p] [p]“We can tell you how to go safely – on one condition,” the blue head says. “Come with us on a tour of the library. No one has visited us since our librarian was eaten by the Swamp Thing.”[/p] [p]You don't seem to have a choice. You follow the monsters into the library.[/p] [p]At first, it looks like an ordinary library, filled with bookshelves. But then you glance at the books. They're all about monsters! You see the titles [em]Frankenstein, Godzilla[/em], and [em]Dracula[/em] . You notice a monster cookbook, a monster travel book, and monster encyclopedias.[/p] [p]“The best books are in the next room,” the red head sneers. “Our favorite stories are all there.”[/p] [p]But you've stopped listening. In a corner of the room, you've spotted a door labeled TO THE CRYPT. Could it be the way out?[/p]
p.next: If you make a run for the crypt
If you decide to stay and wait for the monster to help

p.text: [p]You run for the dining room.[/p] [p]But Nick clamps a clawed, green hand on your wrist. “Afraid of a little blood? What a wimp!”[/p] [p]You try to struggle free, but Nick holds on tight.[/p] [p]“You've failed the test!” Connor announces. He points to the watch on his thick hairy wrist. “It's already one minute to midnight!”[/p] [p]“What?” you cry. You try to glance at your own watch, but Nick is gripping your arm too hard. “I've only started searching,” you protest. “I've still got plenty of time!”[/p] [p]“But we're running on [em]monster[/em] time!” Nick taunts with an evil grin. “And by our clock – your time has run out!”[/p] [p]“No!” you scream. “No!”[/p] [p]With all your strength you pull your arm free from Nick.[/p] [p]You glance at your watch.[/p] [p]Magically, it too reads one minute to midnight![/p] [p]Then you glance at your wrist again. And scream.[/p] [p]Thick brown hair is growing on your arm! And your legs … and all over you![/p] [p]And now claws are sprouting where your fingernails once were.[/p] [p]Too bad! From the look of it, you're on monster time now, too.[/p] [p]Forever![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You read the list again. Then you start to laugh. [em]These guys really take this Horror Club stuff seriously[/em], you think. Still laughing, you point to the list and say, “Great joke. Very funny.”[/p] [p]“Why are you laughing?” Connor demands.[/p] [p]“This list – it's a riot,” you reply. You wonder why no one else has even cracked a smile.[/p] [p]“It's not a joke,” Nick insists. “That's the list for our scavenger hunt.”[/p] [p]“Give me a break,” you say. “You expect me to believe that? Where would I find those things?”[/p] [p]“In this house,” Debbie replies matter-of-factly.[/p] [p]“Yeah, right,” you scoff. “I'm supposed to believe that there really are werewolves, and witches, and mummies?”[/p] [p]“It's true,” Connor says.[/p] [p]“Do you want me to prove it?” Nick asks with an evil grin. A very evil grin.[/p]

[p]You dash toward the mummy case. You quickly jump in and slam the lid shut. You stand stiffly in the darkness, scarcely daring to breathe. Waiting.[/p] [p]You can hear the king's guards coming closer. Did they see you hide?[/p] [p]No! Their footsteps thunder past you, and you exhale with relief.[/p] [p]You wait several minutes, wondering if it is okay to climb out. You decide to wait a little bit more, when the lid suddenly springs open.[/p] [p]You poke your head out in terror.[/p] [p]But no one's there – and the blue sky and flowers are gone! You're in a dimly lit hallway.[/p] [p]You step out and almost knock into a mummy. A [em]sleeping[/em] mummy![/p] [p]“Oh, no!” you cry out. “I'm back in Bat Wing Hall.”[/p] [p]You glance at your watch. Only half an hour left before you turn into a monster! You have to complete the scavenger hunt! You've got to get moving![/p] [p]You need to grab a piece of the sleeping mummy's bandage. There's no time to waste![/p]

[p]“I'll help you,” you tell Professor Krupnik.[/p] [p]“Good,” the ghost growls. “Now get these kids out of Bat Wing Hall. And make sure they never come back.”[/p] [p]It's weird that a ghost would need your help. But you do as Professor Krupnik asks. When you get to the mansion, you peer in through a window and see Marcie, Martin, and Lara sitting on the floor and talking.[/p] [p]How can you make them leave?[/p] [p]You know that it will be hard to scare them away. After all, they're members of the Horror Club. But maybe it would be different if they knew that the house really is haunted.[/p] [p]Or – maybe it would be better to come up with a better place for the Horror Club to meet.[/p] [p]Which will it be?[/p]
p.next: To convince them the house is haunted
To get them to move to a new place

p.text: [p]You watch, horrified, as the red sun sinks into the distance. At the same moment, you feel hairs sprouting all over your body. Your shoulders start to ache as your arms turn into bat wings. A moment later, you're hovering over the heads of your friends.[/p] [p]Lara lets out a scream. Marcie's jaw has dropped open so wide you can see her fillings. Martin looks impressed.[/p] [p]“Did you see what happened?” Marcie exclaims. “The story was true!”[/p] [p]“I wouldn't believe it if I hadn't seen it!” Martin says.[/p] [p]“Did you say you need our help?” Lara asks you. She seems frightened, but also concerned.[/p] [p]“I need you to help me close the Krupnik Crypt,” you squeak. But they can't understand your bat language.[/p] [p]How can you get them to help you now? You start to fly across the street, toward the cemetery. Your friends only watch you, puzzled.[/p] [p]“Maybe it's hungry,” Lara suggests. “Should we catch some insects for it?”[/p] [p]Frustrated, you fly back to your waiting friends. Again, you fly toward the cemetery, again you return.[/p] [p]“I know what it's doing!” Martin says suddenly.[/p]

[p]Your heart thuds as you approach the closet door. The pool of blood grows larger on the floor. Slowly, you pull the door open.[/p] [p]And gasp.[/p] [p]There's no dead body in the closet. No dead anything. Only a broken jar. A jar of raspberry jam, dripping onto the floor.[/p] [p]You sigh with relief and explore the closet further. The shelves are crammed with rusty cans of vegetables and moldy sacks of flour. You quickly search all the shelves, but find nothing.[/p] [p]Then you spot it. A plastic shoe box on the bottom shelf.[/p] [p]You reach down and open it. You can't believe your eyes![/p] [p]Nestled in the center of the box, on a dark piece of cloth, is the skeleton of a human hand![/p] [p]“Oh, gross,” you moan. You try not to wonder whose hand it was and how it got in this box.[/p] [p]“You found our skeleton in the closet!” Debbie sings out.[/p] [p]You nod. You're glad you found something on the list, but you don't want to touch the hand. You start to carry the box away from the closet. But Nick stops you.[/p] [p]“The list says [em]one[/em] bone from a human hand, not the whole hand,” he reminds you. His reptile tongue darts in and out of his mouth.[/p] [p]You stare down at the hand. One bone![/p]

[p]“I choose the glowing red stone,” you tell the wizard.[/p] [p]Silently the wizard hands it to you.[/p] [p]The red stone is strangely warm in your hand, and it seems to be vibrating. You can feel its slow throbbing.[/p] [p]As you stare at the stone, it glows brighter and brighter. The heat from the stone seeps through your hand, spreading warmth to your arm. Then to your whole body.[/p] [p]You begin to sweat. Your temperature rises.[/p] [p]The priests begin chanting.[/p] [p]You grow hotter. Hotter. Hotter![/p] [p]The chanting voices fade in and out.[/p] [p][em]I'm burning up![/em] you think frantically.[/p] [p]A yellow light suddenly flashes before your eyes. The light is so incredibly bright you have to shut your eyes.[/p] [p]When you open them, you are in a dark hallway. And your body feels okay. Not too hot. Not too cold.[/p] [p]You gaze around in amazement.[/p] [p]You are back in Bat Wing Hall! You're safe![/p]

[p]Nick's just trying to scare you, you think. He's testing you, to see if you're brave enough for the Horror Club.[/p] [p]You shrug and rush forward. You dash across the porch and squeeze through a narrow space in the boards covering the front door. You land on your knees with a thud.[/p] [p]As soon as you hit the floor, a piercing alarm sounds through the house. What's going on? you wonder.[/p] [p]You gaze around quickly. Nick and Debbie are nowhere to be found. The dark house seems empty. You hold your ears, trying to block out the horrible noise. And then, through a dusty window, you see lights. Red, whirling lights.[/p] [p]The police![/p] [p]You have set off a burglar alarm. Now you're in big trouble! How will you ever explain this to the police – or to your mom and dad?[/p] [p]Too bad! It looks as if your adventure is over even before it began![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“I'm going to trust you,” you tell Debbie. “Please help me get out of here!”[/p] [p]“A wise choice!” Debbie sneers. She glances over her shoulder, then beckons you to follow her. “Be quiet,” she warns. “There's no telling what Nick and Connor will do if they find out!”[/p] [p]You creep down a long dark hall behind Debbie. The tarantulas squirm wildly through her hair. You are glad Debbie, with her gross purple face, is really a friend.[/p] [p]Then you reach the end of the hall.[/p] [p]And there stand Nick and Connor. Saliva drips from their mouths as they smack their lips.[/p] [p]Then seven-foot-tall Connor lumbers toward you. His enormous arms reach for you.[/p] [p]You glance back at Debbie for help.[/p] [p]She's your friend – right?[/p]

[p]You follow the left-hand path along the river. The whole time you wonder: Where am I? How will I ever get home?[/p] [p]You feel eyes on you – creatures' eyes. Staring at you. You whirl around, searching, but you see no one.[/p] [p]Then you hear a sound you can't ignore. Footsteps. Heavy, heavy footsteps. The footsteps of something very big. And very, very close. [em]THUMP … THUMP … THUMP …[/em][/p] [p]You freeze. The footsteps stop. You glance behind you, but all you can see is the swirling mist.[/p] [p]Maybe it was nothing. You start up again, but so do the steps! [em]THUMP … THUMP … THUMP![/em] They're getting closer. You don't dare look back.[/p] [p]You try to run, but your feet sink into the marshy ground. The thing is almost right behind you![/p] [p]And then, just ahead, you spot a cave. You can hide in there. You race to the cave. A sign beside it says MONSTER LIBRARY. You have no idea what a Monster Library is, but you don't care. Anything would be better than this swamp with a [em]thing[/em] following you. You duck inside.[/p] [p]Oh, no! The thing behind you runs in, too.[/p]

[p]“I choose the Red Team,” you announce.[/p] [p]“Fine,” Marcie says. “The Red Team will stay in the house for the games. The Blue Team will go outside. See you later!”[/p] [p]Marcie, Lara, and Martin leave the house.[/p] [p]You turn to your new teammates with a smile. You're looking forward to the games.[/p] [p]“I'm glad you're on our team,” Nick says. “We're having a scavenger hunt. Everything has to be found inside the house.”[/p] [p]“Cool,” you reply. “I love scavenger hunts. Where's the list?”[/p] [p]“Here it is,” Debbie says, handing you a piece of white paper.[/p] [p]You read the list of items out loud:[/p] [p class="handwritten"]“HORROR CLUB SCAVENGER HUNT[br /] – one human bone[br /] – three hairs from a werewolf[br /] – a straw from a witch's broom[br /] – a piece from a mummy's bandage.”[/p]

[p]There's no way you're hanging around with some Egyptian king![/p] [p]“Thanks for the invitation,” you say politely, “but I'd like to leave.”[/p] [p]The king shows you to the door, and you step outside, into a beautiful garden filled with flowers. Red, purple, orange – flowers of every kind, in every hue. The sky shines a brilliant blue, and you fill your lungs with the sweet-smelling air. You want to jump for joy.[/p] [p]You spot something familiar in the distance, something leaning against a tree. A mummy case! It looks like the same mummy case you found in Bat Wing Hall.[/p] [p]“Get him! There he is!” someone shouts from behind you.[/p] [p]You reel around – it's the king. Uh-oh, you mumble to yourself. Looks as if the king changed his mind.[/p] [p]His men come charging toward you. You gaze frantically around the garden. At the far edge is a thicket of tall reeds. You could hide there.[/p] [p]Quick! Do something![/p]
p.next: To hide in the mummy case
To run for the reeds

p.text: [p]Nick begins his story. “There once were three kids. They looked like kids you'd meet every day at school or in the playground. But these kids were different. They were under an evil spell – a spell that turned them into monsters. And there was only one way to release them from it.”[/p] [p]“What's that?” Connor asks, leaning forward.[/p] [p]“They had to find another kid who would pass a horrible, deadly test. No kid had ever completed the test and lived to tell about it,” Nick continues in a low voice. “The test was a scavenger hunt, and the kid would have to find four creepy – impossible – things. Only then would the monsters change back to kids.”[/p] [p]“What happened?” Debbie asks breathlessly.[/p] [p]You stand up and head for the front door. You're going home. You have a funny feeling you know exactly how this story is going to[/p] [p class="end"]END[/p]

[p]Great choice![/p] [p]Now you're stuck at home with nothing to do. Sure, you can clean out your closet. Or play stupid board games with your little brother. But that doesn't change things.[/p] [p]You still have no friends. You're still bored.[/p] [p]But wait – you have one last chance![/p] [p]You hurry to the big yellow phone book. You look up Nick's phone number. You grab the phone and dial. It rings. And rings.[/p] [p]And then you hear Nick's voice. “Hello?”[/p]

[p]You don t want to spend the rest of your life as a bat. You've got to get to the crypt. You decide to fly. Luckily, the window is slightly open. You duck through it and glide out into the cool evening air.[/p] [p]You realize you need to practice using your wings. First you try flapping, then you soar up and down. It's kind of fun, dipping and swooping over the backyard.[/p] [p]You also like your cool sonar system. Through your super bat's ears, you're able to hear thousands of times better than you could as a human. Insects sound as loud as cars did when you were a kid.[/p] [p]Something makes a flapping sound to your right. Without even looking, your sonar tells you it's a gnat. A thundering buzz, like the sound of a chain saw, comes from a June bug. You can not only tell [em]what[/em] sects are, you can tell [em]where[/em] they are.[/p] [p]Your sonar informs you that a large moth is fluttering in the trees just ahead. The thought of the moth makes your mouth water. You realize you're very, very hungry.[/p] [p]A [em]moth?[/em] going to eat a moth?[/p]

[p]“Lara!” You call. “Martin! Marcie!”[/p] [p]The only answer is the wind rustling through the trees. Your eyes search the cemetery, but your gaze falls only on crumbling headstones. You glance across the street at the mansion, but it's completely dark. Has everyone gone home?[/p] [p]Another bat flies by and you decide not to wait around. You race out of the cemetery and head for home.[/p] [p]Later that night, you don't feel very well. Your shoulders ache and your fingers feel stiff.[/p] [p]Maybe you're getting sick. You hope not. You don't want to miss soccer practice. You climb into bed and drift into a troubled sleep. When you awaken a few hours later, it's still dark, and you feel even worse.[/p] [p]Maybe a drink of water would make you feel better. As you get up, you notice that your hands seem to be very stiff. You glance down and see something dark between all your fingers.[/p] [p][em]It must be the shadows in the room[/em], you think. Your feet don't seem to be working very well, but somehow you make your way to the bathroom. You reach up to flip on the fight. But the light switch isn't where it's supposed to be.[/p] [p]Instead, it's three feet above you! And the bathroom mirror is even higher.[/p]

[p]You hurry down the hall after the mummy. There's not much time. You still need three more items for the scavenger hunt. There doesn't seem to be any other way to get out of Bat Wing Hall.[/p] [p]As you continue, the putrid smell grows stronger.[/p] [p]Then, at the end of the hall, you see a beautiful, gold mummy case. And leaning against the wall beside it is the mummy![/p] [p]The mummy's head rests on the case. Strange snorting noises come from under its bandages. With a start, you realize that the noises are snores. The mummy is asleep![/p] [p]You know that a piece of a mummy's bandage is on the list. But what's the best way to get one?[/p] [p]You spot some torn pieces of bandage inside the mummy case. Should you take a piece from there?[/p] [p]Or should you try to pull a strip off of the sleeping mummy?[/p] [p]Either way, you'd better hurry. It's less than an hour until midnight![/p]
p.next: To take a piece of bandage from the case
To tear a strip off the mummy

p.text: [p]“Okay,” you tell the witch. “I'll try to help you.”[/p] [p]“You won't regret it,” she promises. “Hurry around to the back of the box.”[/p] [p]You do as she says. On the back of the clear box are two hand prints. “Place your hands on the prints,” the witch instructs. Once again, you follow her request.[/p] [p]“Now repeat after me: [em]Arikarem. Amikaroo.[/em] ”[/p] [p]You chant the magic words.[/p] [p]“Now clap your hands,” she says. You clap.[/p] [p]Nothing happens. You clap again. Still nothing.[/p] [p]“What's going on?” you demand impatiently.[/p] [p]“I must have given you the wrong spell,” she admits. “I'm a little rusty with my magic after all these years. Now [em]what[/em] hose words?”[/p] [p]“Hurry!” you cry. It's ten minutes until midnight! You try to pull your hands away from the box. But they are stuck – as if they were glued! “Hurry,” you urge her again.[/p] [p]“I've got it!” she announces. ``Say the words: [em]Spmubesoog. Spmubesoog.[/em] [/p] [p]You notice the witch has her fingers crossed – not a good sign! You repeat the magic words.[/p]

[p]A huge, dark shadow looms at the end of the street. It's the mansion.[/p] [p]You stop walking and gaze up at it. Nick shines his flashlight at the old house on the hill.[/p] [p]Bat Wing Hall is a two-story, old-fashioned house. All the windows that aren't boarded up are broken. Loose shingles flap from the roof. Paint peels from the weathered sides of the house. It looks as if no one has lived here for hundreds of years.[/p] [p]You climb up to the sagging porch with Nick and Debbie. Tall, overgrown trees and bushes cast eerie shadows across the deserted lawn.[/p] [p]“Isn't this place awesome?” Debbie whispers to you.[/p] [p]“Really cool,” you agree.[/p] [p]“This house has been empty for two years,” Nick tells you. “Ever since crazy old Professor Krupnik died.”[/p] [p]“No one will buy it because it's haunted,” Debbie explains. You notice she's chewing nervously at the ends of her long hair. Yuck![/p] [p]“The front door was boarded up until we figured out how to pry it open,” Debbie says. She points to the large wooden door. “Let's go.”[/p] [p]You take a step forward.[/p] [p]“Stop!” Nick shouts. “Get down! Now!”[/p]
p.next: If you do as Nick says
If you ignore him and head for the door

p.text: [p]It's a huge black rat – and it scurries across your sneaker! You jump back and scream.[/p] [p]You can hear the rat's sharp claws scratch across the floorboards as it disappears into the living room. You wonder what other gross creatures are crawling around this old house.[/p] [p]You decide to head into the kitchen. [em]Clomp. Clomp. Clomp.[/em] You can hear Nick, Debbie, and Connor following you.[/p] [p]“If you're afraid of a little rat,” Nick hisses in your ear, “then you're going to be in big trouble later. Big trouble.”[/p] [p]You try to ignore Nick, even though your knees shake at his warning. You spot a kerosene lamp on the kitchen table. You pick it up so you can see into the dark corners of the kitchen better.[/p] [p]The kitchen is filled with cupboards, closets, and shelves. Anything could be hidden here![/p] [p]You pull open drawer after drawer. Clouds of dust make your eyes itch.[/p] [p]Then in the next drawer you open, you see them.[/p] [p]Bandages! But are these mummy's bandages?[/p] [p]You hope they are, shoving several in your pocket. [em]One item off the list[/em], you think.[/p] [p]Then a hideous scream cuts through the air.[/p]

[p]You fly toward the ring and perch on it. You take a moment to look each of your friends directly in the eyes.[/p] [p]“You have to turn the ring!” you instruct. “You have to close the door to the crypt!”[/p] [p]“What's it squeaking about?” Martin asks.[/p] [p]“I don't know,” Lara replies. “But it seems to have something to do with the ring on the door.”[/p] [p]Marcie has been peering intently at the door. “I think this door used to be closed,” she says. “Maybe that's what it's telling us. Maybe it wants us to shut the door.”[/p] [p]“Yes, yes, yes!” you squeak. You're so happy you could kiss her, but you figure it would gross her out.[/p] [p]Marcie begins to push on the door. It barely budges.[/p] [p]“Let me help!” says Martin. He pushes, too, and then Lara joins in, but the door hardly moves.[/p] [p]“It's too heavy!” Marcie complains. “We can't shut it.”[/p] [p]Oh, no! What are you going to do?[/p]

[p]You run as fast as you can into the thicket of tall reeds. Then you duck down and gaze through the tall stalks.[/p] [p]The guards have stopped. They appear to be arguing. One of them points to the thicket. Oh, no! But the others shake their heads violently. They turn around and head back for the palace.[/p] [p]What happened? you wonder. Why won't they go into the thicket?[/p] [p]You shrug and decide not to worry about it. You have more important things to think about – like how to get home![/p] [p]Suddenly, you hear a rustling noise. [em]In fact[/em], you think, [em]it sounds more like a rattle[/em] . You glance down and let out a wail of terror![/p] [p]A huge black snake is coiled at your feet![/p] [p]The snake's leathery body is thicker than your two legs put together![/p] [p]The snake lifts its head and hisses. Then it opens its mouth. Wider. Wider. Wider. Its long tongue uncurls and darts out at you. Oh, no! The snake is going to swallow you whole![/p]

[p]“Haunted? For real?” you ask.[/p] [p]“For real,” Nick replies seriously. “That's why we picked it. Some of the scariest stories I've ever heard happened in Bat Wing Hall.”[/p] [p]“Like what?”[/p] [p]“Like the story of the kids on Halloween night,” Nick says. “They were all dressed up. Trick-or-treating. They rang Krupnik's doorbell. A figure dressed all in black answered, and the kids were invited inside … only they [em]never[/em] came out!”[/p] [p]“What happened?” you ask breathlessly.[/p] [p]“Nobody knows,” Nick replies. “But late at night you can still hear the kids' screams. Horrible screams. And when the moon is full – some people say they've seen little creatures in monster costumes roaming about inside the house! Trapped. Forever!”[/p] [p]“Wow! Great story!” you say.[/p] [p]“It's [em]not[/em] a story,” Nick tells you. “Being a member of the Horror Club can be dangerous. [em]Very[/em] dangerous.” He pauses, then adds, “Today is Friday. We meet tonight. Do you want to come?”[/p] [p]What do you think?[/p]
p.next: Risk it and go to the Horror Club tonight
Say thanks anyway and go

p.text: [p]You decide to try to act like a wolf.[/p] [p]Very carefully, you drop the broom. Then you get down on your hands and knees. The werewolf backs off, confused.[/p] [p][em]So far, so good[/em], you think. You tilt your head back and howl. A long mournful howl.[/p] [p]The werewolf howls back![/p] [p]You start to crawl toward the beast, sniffing the ground like an animal. You glance up. The werewolf is staring at you intently. Will he attack? you wonder.[/p] [p]You continue with your wolf act. You crawl until you are just inches away from him. You raise your head again when – he pounces![/p] [p]The beast knocks you to the ground. You stare up in terror. His vicious fangs are less than an inch from your face! His mouth opens –[/p] [p]And then he starts to lick your nose![/p] [p]He thinks you are another werewolf. He likes you – a lot! He licks your cheeks, your nose, your neck, your fur. Fur?[/p] [p]You hear the last gong of a chiming clock in the distance. And Nick, Debbie, and Connor's uproarious laughter. With a sinking heart, you realize it is midnight. The game is over.[/p] [p]You acted your part well. Too well. Now you're a werewolf forever! Well, at least you made a friend![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You remember the Krupnik Crypt. And that the only [em]living[/em] creature you saw was the bat that flew out of the tomb. With a gnawing fear, your mind plays over the words carved in the crypt:[/p] [p class="centered"]WHO TURNS THE STONE WILL GROW BAT BONES.[/p] [p]You should have realized it was a warning. But no, you had to go ahead and turn that stupid stone![/p] [p]That must have been how this happened. You try frantically to remember everything about the crypt, any little detail that could help you. You picture the crypt and suddenly recall that you'd left the stone door open. Maybe if you turn the stone again – closing the door of the crypt – you'll be transformed back.[/p] [p]Should you return to the cemetery now? You're not sure you can even find it in the dark.[/p] [p]Or would it be better to go to sleep and wait until morning? Maybe when you wake up, you'll be back to normal.[/p]
p.next: If you return to the cemetery now
If you wait until morning

p.text: [p]It's amazing! Marcie, Lara, and Martin are acting as if they see ghosts every day. So much for scaring them out of the mansion! You need a new plan. Lara eyes Professor Krupnik. “What's it like to be a ghost?” she asks. The ghost seems startled by the question. “It's … it's …” he stammers. Now Marcie and Martin swarm around him, firing questions at him. “Can you appear in other forms?” “How long have you been a ghost?” “What do you do all day?” To your amazement, the ghost starts to smile. He holds up his shadowy hands. “Slow down. I can answer only one question at a time.” He actually seems to be enjoying the attention! Maybe it's lonely being a ghost. You get a great idea. “Fellow teammates,” you announce. “I nominate Professor Krupnik as the newest member of the Horror Club.” When you see the grin on the ghost's face, you know this was the perfect solution. Just in time, too. After a unanimous vote, Professor Krupnik mutters some strange words and waves his arms. Whatever he did, it worked! The sun drops below the horizon – and you're still a kid! You settle down to listen to the ghost's scary stories, thrilled that this adventure has come to a happy[/p] [p class="end"]END[/p]

[p]As fast as you can fly, you head for the kitchen.[/p] [p]“Stop!” Marcie shrieks, running after you.[/p] [p]There's got to be a way out! Your heart and wings are beating furiously as you search the kitchen. But the door and all the windows are shut. The only other way out is the doorway you flew in – and Marcie's standing there with the flyswatter![/p] [p]“I'm not really a bat!” you plead as loudly as you can. “I've been transformed!”[/p] [p]“You filthy beast!” Marcie screams. She heads straight for you, the flyswatter raised, ready to smash you. She manages to whack you, hard. You bang into the wall, your head spinning. One more blow like that, and it will be all over. Oh, no! Here she comes again! Your eyes dart all around the room.[/p] [p]Just ahead you notice a large, standing freezer. It's open just a crack. In desperation, you fly into the crack.[/p] [p]“I've got you now!” Marcie cries, and slams the freezer shut.[/p] [p]“Hey!” you call. “Let me out of here!”[/p] [p]But there's no answer. Marcie won't let you out,[/p] [p]you realize, until you're frozen solid. Too bad, but you made the wrong choice. And it looks as if you'll end this adventure as a batsicle![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“I have all the items on the list,” you announce as you enter the dark living room. “I found the human bone, mummy's bandage, the witch's broom, and I even got three hairs from a were –”[/p] [p]“What are you talking about?” Nick interrupts.[/p] [p]You gasp. You can't believe your eyes.[/p] [p]There sit Nick, Debbie, and Connor in a circle on the living room floor. But they're not monsters! They look like normal kids![/p] [p]“What happened?” you cry. “Why did you change back?”[/p] [p]“Change back?” Debbie asks, running a hand through her long – spider-free – hair. “Change back from what?”[/p] [p]“From monsters,” you say. “Come on, you guys. I know what you really are. Don't play any more games.”[/p] [p]“Hey, Nick,” Connor says. “Your new friend is nuts. Monsters! Ha! That's a good one.”[/p] [p]“But – but the scavenger hunt. And the mummy and the skeleton,” you try to explain. The three kids stare at you with blank expressions as you stammer.[/p] [p]“Listen,” Debbie tells you, standing up and leading you to their circle. “You're just in time for Nick's very spooky story.”[/p] [p]You sit on the floor, your mind spinning.[/p]

[p]They want you to search the cemetery all by yourself. You're about to say [em]No way, Jose[/em], but then you figure that's just what they expect you to do.[/p] [p]You'll show them![/p] [p]“Great!” you declare. “I bet I'll find the winning object.” You even kind of mean it. After all, if the game is won by finding the scariest stuff, then your teammates just handed you an easy score. What better place to look than a cemetery? You give your teammates the thumbs up, and hurry across the street.[/p] [p]The cemetery is really old, and most of the gravestones are chipped and crumbling. As you stumble over a lumpy grave, you feel something grab at your ankle! You yelp and jump back.[/p] [p]Phew! It was just a gnarled root.[/p] [p]The moonlight casts an eerie glow, creating strange shadows. You carefully make your way toward a small building. There's just enough light for you to read the words KRUPNIK CRYPT carved in the stone over the doorway.[/p] [p]Here's your chance to impress your new friends. You know you will find something scary inside a crypt. But do you have the nerve to enter?[/p]

[p]“What?” you cry.[/p] [p]“I've been imprisoned in this magic box for two centuries,” the witch goes on. “All this time I've waited for someone to set me free.”[/p] [p]“Really?” you say doubtfully. This sounds a lot like those fairy tales your mom used to read to you when you were five years old.[/p] [p]“Please help me,” the woman pleads.[/p] [p]You glance at your watch. And then over to the broom. “I'd like to help you,” you say. “But I have to find a straw from a witch's broom really fast. Otherwise, I'll turn into a monster.”[/p] [p]“Well, I'm a witch,” the woman tells you. “And I have a broom. Help me, and I'll help you.”[/p] [p]“If you're a witch, can't you say a spell to escape?” you ask.[/p] [p]“Don't you think I've already tried that?” the witch spits back. “It didn't work.”[/p] [p]Your gaze travels from the witch to the broom and back to your watch. Only fifteen minutes until midnight. What should you do?[/p]
p.next: If you choose to help the witch
If you decide to leave her in the box and grab her broom

p.text: [p]“Let's go to the movie,” you suggest. It will give you time to think of a way to ask for help.[/p] [p]You line up for tickets and popcorn and then settle into your seats. “This movie is supposed to be really scary,” Lara says with a shiver.[/p] [p]As soon as the lights start to dim, you feel a familiar ache in your shoulders. With horror, you look down at your hands. The webbing is growing in between your fingers![/p] [p]“I'm going to the bathroom,” you mumble, and quickly jump out of your seat. The next instant, you're a bat![/p] [p]You can't stay in the aisle of the theater where someone could step on you, so you fly up to the ceiling. Down below you hear laughter.[/p] [p]“Look at that!” someone cries. “A real bat! It must be a part of the movie!”[/p] [p]“What a publicity stunt,” someone shouts.[/p] [p]Will you [em]tell[/em] your friends the truth about what happened to you now?[/p] [p]Or would it be better to [em]show[/em] them – back at Bat Wing Hall?[/p]
p.next: If you tell them now
If you think it's wiser to show them

p.text: [p]You run to the mansion as fast as you can. You don't want to find out who or [em]what[/em] would make a sound like that! When you've put some distance between you and the voice, you glance back. Nothing. Maybe you were just imagining things.[/p] [p]Just to be safe, though, you quickly pull the boards away from the door and enter Bat Wing Hall. You find a good spot to hide, behind a tattered armchair – why take chances? You curl up and wait.[/p] [p]Your aching muscles tell you you've been sitting there for a lot longer than an hour. Peering through the smudgy windows, you can see the sun has dropped low on the horizon.[/p] [p]What if your friends don't show up until after you've turned back into a bat?[/p]

[p]The snake's sharp fangs begin to drip with deadly venom.[/p] [p]You start to back away.[/p] [p]“Don't move!” a voice behind you cries.[/p] [p]You freeze. And then you hear music. A strange, joyous melody.[/p] [p]The snake seems to hear the music, too. Its head starts to sway back and forth, back and forth. Almost as if it were dancing.[/p] [p]“Move away slowly now,” the voice instructs you. You do as you're told and bump into a small round man playing a wooden flute.[/p] [p]The man stops playing, and the snake slithers away.[/p] [p]“It is very stupid to enter the thicket of the snake,” the man says. “You must be new here.”[/p] [p]“I don't belong here at all,” you tell him. “I ended up here by accident.”[/p] [p]“This has happened before,” the man replies. “And I bet the priests want to turn you into a mummy – right?”[/p] [p]“Yes,” you cry. “What can I do?”[/p] [p]“I'm afraid things look hopeless for you,” he says, shaking his head. “There's only one way out.”[/p]

[p]“Upstairs,” you tell the monsters. “I'll search there first.”[/p] [p]Connor begins laughing. A low, deep laugh. “Did you hear that?” he tells the others. “Upstairs! This should be good!”[/p] [p]Have you made the wrong choice? you wonder. It doesn't matter. You have to do something. You cross your fingers that there may be a way to escape upstairs – a way out of this house of horrors.[/p] [p]You head toward the main staircase in the front hall. There's no electricity in the old mansion. Your shadow flickers in the spooky light of kerosene lanterns.[/p] [p]Debbie follows close behind you. You pick up your pace – just in case one of those huge tarantulas decides to jump from her hair to yours![/p] [p]The stairs are covered with a thick layer of dust. Slowly you start to climb. One step. Then another. The wooden boards creak and groan under your weight. The staircase stretches upward into total darkness.[/p] [p]Behind you, the three monsters noisily whisper to each other. You don't know what they're saying – and you don't care. You just want to get out of here – now![/p] [p]You take a deep breath. It's time.[/p] [p]Time to – escape![/p] [p]You sprint forward.[/p]

[p]You decide your best bet is to fly into the crypt. You hope your friends will get the idea to shut the door. First, you swoop around the door to the crypt.[/p] [p]“What's it doing?” Lara asks her friends.[/p] [p]“I think it's trying to tell us the door is important,” Marcie says.[/p] [p]“Yes!” you squeak. This might actually work! You fly into the crypt. Then you fly out again.[/p] [p]Martin cries, “I get it! We're supposed to close the door!”[/p] [p]You squeak happily and nod. You fly out of the crypt and watch while Martin grasps the ring then pushes the door.[/p] [p][em]Clang![/em] The door slams shut. But nothing happens. Then you feel a tingling sensation in your wings. A moment later, you're standing on the ground. You're a kid again![/p] [p]“Hooray!” you cry. “It worked!”[/p] [p]“Cool!” Marcie says. “But where did Martin go?”[/p] [p]You glance all around, but there's no sign of your friend.[/p] [p]“Oh, no!” Lara suddenly cries. “Look!” Your eyes follow where she's pointing. You see a large bat above your heads. It's fluttering very strangely, as if it doesn't really know how to fly. Uh-oh.[/p]

[p]It's probably not a good idea to ignore a command like that. Your heart thudding in your chest, you stop and turn in the direction of the voice.[/p] [p]At first you're surprised that the figure before you is just an old man with a long white beard. You're a little embarrassed that you were so afraid. But then you notice that the old guy's shape keeps shifting, as if he were made out of gray mist. And your jaw drops when you realize you can see right through him.[/p] [p]“I am the spirit of Professor Krupnik!” the old man bellows. He glares at you. “You've been disturbing my peace for the last two years! Now I will get my revenge!”[/p] [p]You can't believe it! You're face-to-face with a ghost – and it's mad at you![/p] [p]“I haven't done anything!” you quake. “I moved to town only last week!”[/p] [p]“Do you deny that you're a member of the Horror Club?!” the professor thunders.[/p] [p]“Well, but … but …” you stammer. “But I just joined –”[/p] [p]“Silence!” the ghost shouts. “I've heard enough!” It reaches out for you. You feel an icy chill throughout your body.[/p] [p]Is this the end?[/p]

[p]You turn and sprint for the front door. But the entrance is blocked by Connor. He grabs your shoulder. And you nervously stare up at him – way up.[/p] [p]Connor has turned into a seven-foot-tall giant with one red eye in the middle of his forehead. And the stench coming off his body is unbearable! “Where are you going?” he growls.[/p] [p]“I, uh, I need to go home,” you mumble. You duck under Connor's massive arm and lunge for the doorknob. And miss.[/p] [p]The monster that used to be Nick beat you to it. Nick locks the door and says, “Not so fast! It's time for the scavenger hunt.”[/p] [p]Scavenger hunt? There's no way you're sticking around to play a game with monsters![/p] [p]Unless this is all a joke. [em]Hey, that's it[/em], you think. [em]It's all a joke. They must be wearing monster costumes.[/em] [/p] [p][em]No![/em] you think again. [em]They can't be wearing costumes. They're way too real-looking.[/em][/p] [p][em]Quick – you have to make up your mind![/em][/p]
p.next: If you're sure it's all a joke
If you believe the monsters are real

p.text: [p]You decide not to risk breaking off a straw.[/p] [p]You stand in front of the tiny elevator with the broom. You scratch your head. The broom is definitely too tall. And the elevator opening is too short. How will you possibly make this broom fit?[/p] [p]you wonder.[/p] [p]Time is ticking away. You have only one choice. You turn the broom diagonally and try to wedge it through the elevator door. It works![/p] [p]You quickly jump into the elevator yourself – and the floor drops out from beneath your feet! The broom tumbles down the elevator shaft.[/p] [p]You grab for the railing on the elevator wall. There's nothing between you and the basement but air! You hang on, gripping so tightly your knuckles turn white.[/p] [p]What will you do now? There's no way you can crawl back out. And if you let go, you'll plunge to your death.[/p] [p]“Help!” you cry out. “Help!” But you know no one will help you.[/p] [p]Your fingers start to slip. You try to grip the railing more tightly. But one finger falls away. Then another …[/p]

[p]You spin around to see who's clutching your shoulder and can't believe your eyes![/p] [p]It's a one-handed skeleton![/p] [p]Your heart begins to pound and your bones begin to rattle – louder than a skeleton's bones! You're terrified, but you're angry too. You won that game, fair and square. You deserve to leave.[/p] [p]You kick the skeleton in the shin bone – hard! His hand drops from your shoulder, as he grabs his leg and shrieks in pain.[/p] [p]You jerk the door open and race outside. You sprint down the street. Up your driveway. Into your nice safe house.[/p] [p]You made it out of Bat Wing Hall![/p] [p]You practically crawl into your living room. Your little brother is sitting on the floor, a videogame control in his hand. He's playing [em]Mud Monsters![/em][/p] [p]“Play with me,” he begs.[/p] [p]“Sure!” you say. Little brother – watch out![/p] [p]Up, down, jump! Left, right – [em]SPLAT![/em] [/p] [p]The Mud Monster destroys you with a super mud ball.[/p] [p]Oh, well. You win some. You lose some![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You decide to take a piece of bandage from the mummy case. You tiptoe toward the case. You hold your breath as you pass the sleeping mummy. You know it would be disastrous to wake him.[/p] [p]You spot a torn piece of yellowed bandage caught in a crack in the bottom of the case. You bend over. Your fingers wrap around the fabric. And a bony hand smashes through the bottom of the case and grabs your wrist![/p] [p]“Ahhh!” you scream as you try to wrench free. But the hand has an iron grip. It's pulling you. Pulling you into the mummy case. You kick wildly. You scream and scream. But it's no use. You're in the mummy case now. And then the lid slams shut![/p] [p]Your chest tightens. You begin to sweat. The little bit of air in the case is hot and stale. [em]I'm going to suffocate[/em], you think.[/p] [p]You bang frantically on the fid of the case.[/p] [p]“Help!” you cry. “Help!” But you know there's no way the three monsters are going to save you.[/p] [p]You pound on the lid again. And, to your surprise, it opens![/p]

[p]You fly through the neighborhood, checking out mailboxes. At last you find a box with Lara's last name on it. You glide up to the house, and you see Lara sitting on her bed with the phone beside her. The window's open, but you don't want to fly in and freak her out.[/p] [p]You land quietly on the windowsill when she's not looking. You sneak in and perch on a picture frame above Lara's bed and watch.[/p] [p]She punches a number into the phone. “Hello, Marcie?” she says. “It's Lara. Uh-huh. Right. I've got a cool idea. Can you meet me at the mall tomorrow? Great. Three o'clock at the fountain, okay? 'Bye.”[/p] [p]She hangs up and punches in another number. This time she talks to Martin. She tells him to meet her at the mall, too. Now she punches in another, shorter number.[/p] [p]“Hello, Information?” she says. “I'd like the number of someone who just moved to town.” She tells the operator your name, and writes down the number.[/p] [p]This is great! Lara is going to call you! You like her best of all the kids you've met. Finally, you're making friends in this town.[/p] [p]“I'm right here!” you squeak from the picture frame.[/p]

[p]A bony hand grabs your shoulder.[/p] [p]You turn to face the thing that's got you and let out a scream.[/p] [p]An eight-foot-tall monster is clutching your shoulder. A monster with two hideous heads. One head is blue, with a yellow eye in the middle of its forehead. The other head is red and has huge, six-inch fangs. They are both staring at you.[/p] [p]You pull away from the horrible creature. Doesn't it know staring is rude?[/p] [p]“Where do you think you're going?” the blue head rumbles.[/p] [p]“The – the Monster Library,” you gasp.[/p] [p]“You must have a card to enter,” the red head snaps.[/p] [p]“Sorry, I didn't know,” you tell it. “Besides, I'm just trying to get back home.”[/p] [p]“Where is that?” the red head demands.[/p] [p]“I came here from the Krupnik Crypt,” you reply.[/p] [p]“The Krupnik Crypt!” the blue head cries. “Then you're in worse trouble than you think!”[/p] [p]What could be worse than being trapped by a two-headed monster?[/p]

[p]The king points to the instruments. “First we need to remove your brain.”[/p] [p]“My brain?” you screech.[/p] [p]“Yes,” the king says calmly. “The skinny hook is pushed up your nose until it reaches your brain. Then we wiggle the hook back and forth. Back and forth. To make your brain mushy.”[/p] [p]You break out in a cold sweat. Your heart hammers away in your chest as the king continues to explain.[/p] [p]“Then we take the long spoon, slide it up your nose, and scoop your brain out – a little bit at a time.”[/p] [p]Your stomach feels like it's about to heave. [em]No, this can't be happening to me![/em] you think.[/p] [p]You flail about wildly, trying to escape.[/p] [p]“Now don't make a fuss,” the king says. “It is a great honor.” Then the king nods to the priests, and they begin to unroll the bandages.[/p] [p]Too bad! It looks as if this time you've gotten a little too wrapped up in your adventure![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]Nick suddenly whirls around and spots you! “What are you looking at?” he snarls. His long forked tongue darts out at you.[/p] [p]You ignore him. “Hey, Connor,” you call to the giant monster. “You'd get more points if you squash the grapes [em]before[/em] you get the apples.”[/p] [p]“Who asked you?” Connor booms. But he clicks the control in hand and tries your suggestion. “It worked!” he cries in surprise. Then he grumbles, “Must have been a lucky guess.”[/p] [p]“Not at all,” you tell him. “You just stink at this game.”[/p] [p]“What?” Connor roars. He bolts out of his chair. His head brushes the ceiling. “Why, you puny little –”[/p] [p]“You're so lousy at the game anyone could beat you,” you go on. “Even me!”[/p] [p]Connor's face turns red. His giant arms reach for you.[/p] [p]You dodge them. “Are you afraid to play me?” you continue, even though your knees are shaking.[/p] [p]As you had hoped, Connor grows angrier. And angrier.[/p] [p]“I'm not afraid of anything!” he roars.[/p] [p]“Then let's have a contest,” you offer. “Whoever gets the most points wins. If I win, you have to let me go. If you win, you can turn me into a monster right now. Okay?”[/p]

[p]You have a plan. You'll command the werewolf as if he were a dog. You know from training your own dog, Spots, that it is important to be firm – show the dog that you're the boss.[/p] [p]You hold the broom out in front of you and step forward boldly. You stare the werewolf in the eye.[/p] [p]“SIT!” you instruct in your most commanding voice.[/p] [p]The werewolf snarls. But then he sits.[/p] [p]“Good boy!” You try not to get too excited. “Now STAY!”[/p] [p]The werewolf eyes you but doesn't move a muscle.[/p] [p]“Good!” you praise. Now the hard part. Will you be able to pluck hairs from the beast without him biting your head off?[/p] [p][em]BONG … BONG …[/em] your heart jumps as you recognize the sound of the clock chiming. Chiming midnight![/p] [p][em]BONG … BONG …[/em] you've got to move fast![/p] [p]You step closer to the werewolf. You issue your final command.[/p]

[p]Marcie chases you all over the room, swatting. “Stop!” you squeak. “I'm not a bat! I'm a human!”[/p] [p]But she can't hear your words. How can you get her to recognize you? You glance down at the cardboard letters on the floor and get an idea.[/p] [p]You fake her out with a quick twist and then swoop toward the letters. You grab the “H” and fly up to the top of a bookcase with it. “Put that down!” Marcie shrieks. You put it down all right. You lean it against a book, where she can see it. Then, flying as fast as you can, you snag a letter “E” and place that letter next to the “H.”[/p] [p]Marcie still holds the fly swatter up, ready to hit you. But now she's staring at you curiously.[/p] [p]Quickly, you add the “L” and the “P” to the “H” and “E.”[/p] [p]You've managed to spell “HELP” on top of the bookshelf. You hover near Marcie. If you could cross your webbed fingers, you would. Marcie gazes at the letters on the bookshelf. Then she stares at you. She glances back at the letters. “It was you!” she says finally. “It wasn't Darryl. You made the message!”[/p] [p]You feel like cheering. But all you can do is squeak. Quickly, you swoop back down for more letters.[/p]

[p]Somehow, since you went to bed, your bathroom has grown to ten times its normal size.[/p] [p]Or you've shrunk.[/p] [p][em]I must be dreaming[/em], you think. You climb up on the bathroom sink and stare into the mirror. The face gazing out at you from the mirror isn't your own.[/p] [p]It's the furry face of a small, hairy creature with a short nose, huge ears, and tiny white fangs.[/p] [p]It's the face of a bat![/p] [p]You wink your right eye, and, to your horror, the bat in the mirror winks at the same time. The bat in the mirror is [em]you![/em] [/p] [p]“No!” you scream. It comes out as a tiny squeak.[/p] [p][em]This can't be real[/em], you think. [em]It's got to be a dream, right?[/em] You try to pinch yourself, but you can't work your bat fingers.[/p] [p]You continue to stare at your reflection, horrified. How could this have happened?[/p] [p]You think back over the last evening. You try to remember every detail. You hung out with your new friends at the Horror Club. There was a contest to find the scariest things. And then you remember something else – something that sends a chill down your furry little back![/p]

[p]“What is it?” you ask desperately. “What is the way out?”[/p] [p]The little man sighs. “First, you'll have to come work for me, as a snake charmer,” he says. “Can you play the flute?”[/p] [p]“Well, uh, no,” you reply.[/p] [p]“You'd better learn,” the man warns you. “Otherwise, the snakes here will eat you in one gulp!”[/p] [p]He hands you the flute. You blow into it. The noise that comes out hurts your ears. The snake returns and angrily opens its mouth.[/p] [p]You try again. This time the note sounds better. The snake snaps its mouth shut.[/p] [p]“You'll need to practice ten hours a day,” the little man tells you. “But that's only for three years. Because after three years, you will be allowed to return home. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going off to eat lunch.”[/p] [p]As soon as he's gone, you start to put down the flute and leave. But the huge snake hisses violently at you. It opens its mouth threateningly.[/p] [p]With a sigh, you pick up the flute again. You always hated piano lessons, but this is ridiculous! You're sure that no kid ever had to worry about getting eaten if he didn't practice![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You wrench open the orange door, step forward, and plunge down. Down. Down. Cold air whooshes around you as you fall faster. And land with a [em]THUMP![/em] [/p] [p]You sit up slowly and examine yourself. You move your arms and legs. No broken bones. But where are you?[/p] [p]There's a sliver of bright light near your feet. You can reach out in the darkness and feel four walls around you. You're in some sort of closet! And it smells strangely familiar. Like old sweat socks![/p] [p]You gaze behind you in the dim light. T-shirts, jeans, and jackets hang on a rod. Above the rod is one shelf filled with toys. Familiar toys.[/p] [p]With a shock you realize it's [em]your[/em] closet – at home![/p] [p]You open the closet door and step into your bedroom. Morning sunlight pours through the window.[/p] [p]“Time to get up!” you hear your mother call. “Come on, sleepyhead. It's Friday. Only one more day till the weekend.”[/p] [p]Friday! Somehow you have been sent back to your own house on the morning [em]before[/em] you joined the Horror Club! None of the scary things have happened to you – yet.[/p] [p]But they could. It's up to you. Are you brave enough to visit Bat Wing Hall again?[/p]

[p]Nick is right. You'll have to go into the cage.[/p] [p]Still holding the witch's broom, you approach the werewolf. Connor and Debbie laugh, but you focus on the hairy beast. With each step you take, it growls louder. Then, suddenly, the creature whimpers. His ears flatten against his head.[/p] [p]He's afraid, you realize. But of what?[/p] [p]You reach for the cage door. The werewolf whines loudly.[/p] [p]The broom! It's scared of the witch's broom! You don't know why. And you don't care.[/p] [p]You hold the broom in front of you with confidence. You open the door and squeeze into the cage. The beast lunges at you![/p] [p]Quickly, you thrust the broom at it. The werewolf backs off. But only a few paces.[/p] [p]“Nice going, wimp!” Connor taunts. “Only two minutes left!”[/p] [p]The werewolf drops to all fours. He snarls, sniffing at you and the broom. Now he reminds you of a very large dog.[/p] [p][em]Hey[/em], you think, [em]maybe the answer is to treat the werewolf like a dog. Command him the same way you command your own dog.[/em] [/p] [p]Or you could pretend to be a wolf. Maybe that way he will let you get close enough to pluck hairs.[/p] [p][em]Which do you try?[/em][/p]
p.next: If you try to command him
If you pretend to be a wolf

p.text: [p]Nick and Debbie quickly leave your side and huddle together with the other kids. You can hear them arguing. Arguing about you.[/p] [p]Then one voice rises above the others. “But today is game day! You know what that means!”[/p] [p]“I don't,” you suddenly call out. You're sick of standing there. You want to know what's going on.[/p] [p]It works. All six kids stop arguing.[/p] [p]The girl with the red hair steps toward you. “I'm Marcie,” she tells you. “There are no stories tonight. We're playing games instead. But new members can't play. It's the rule.”[/p] [p]“Can't you break the rules just this one time?” you ask.[/p] [p]“These aren't ordinary games,” warns the boy with the large muscles. “These games are scary. Really scary.”[/p] [p]“The scarier the better,” you announce bravely. This starts another argument. Some kids want you to stay and play. Others want you to leave.[/p] [p]Debbie hurries over to your side. Through her mane of dark hair, she whispers, “Go home. Go home now!”[/p] [p]But at that moment, Marcie announces, “It's decided. You can stay and play games with us.”[/p] [p]“Great!” you say, ignoring Debbie. “What are we playing?”[/p]

[p][em]CLANG![/em] The werewolf crashes head-on into the side of the cage. He howls in frustration. His fangs snap at you.[/p] [p]You back up a step. You bite your Up as you stare at the hairy beast.[/p] [p]Familiar laughter fills the room as Nick, Debbie, and Connor slide down the basement's staircase bannister.[/p] [p]“What's the matter?” Nick taunts you. “Not having fun?”[/p] [p]“Only four minutes left,” Connor reminds you, pointing at his small watch. “If you don't get three hairs from the werewolf by then, you'll turn into one of us!”[/p] [p]“But that's not so bad, is it?” Debbie says. “I mean, don't you think I'm beautiful?” She plucks a tarantula from her hair and wiggles it at you. You gaze at her hideous face and shudder. You'll do anything to avoid turning into a monster like her![/p] [p]Cautiously, you step up to the cage. You stick your hand between the iron bars. Slowly, slowly you reach for the werewolf.[/p] [p]“[em]WRROOWL![/em] ” The beast's jaws snap at your fingers, barely missing them. You pull your hand back, trembling.[/p] [p]“There's only one way to get the hairs,” Nick says. “You'll have to go into the werewolf's cage.”[/p]

[p]You've decided to make your friends move the club. You need to come up with some place better to meet than Bat Wing Hall. Then an idea comes to you. You know they won't be able to resist a challenge.[/p] [p]“I'm sorry I'm late,” you tell them, entering the living room. “I was at the graveyard. I found a way cool place for us to meet. But it might be too scary for you guys.”[/p] [p]“No way!” Martin protests.[/p] [p]“Are you sure?” you ask them. “Maybe we should wait and ask the other members?”[/p] [p]“Who needs them?” Martin declares. “Let's go for it!”[/p] [p]“Yeah,” Marcie chimes in. “Let's check it out now. If it's spooky enough, it'll be the club's new home.”[/p] [p]Great! That was easier than you thought. You lead your friends to the cemetery. The old gravestones poke out of the ground at odd angles. They're broken and covered with moss, and all their writing has crumbled away.[/p] [p]“Cool!” Marcie crows. “You were right. This is much scarier than Bat Wing Hall. Let's make this –” she stops suddenly and stares at the ground in horror.[/p] [p]You wonder what grabbed her attention. Then you see it! Breaking through the surface of the ground is a bony hand![/p]

[p]You slide open the door and lift yourself up into a moonlit room with a slanted ceiling. Old furniture and trunks of clothes are strewn everywhere.[/p] [p]Crouching, you make your way over to a little window. You peer out. And sigh. You are three stories up. You must be in the attic, you realize. There's no way you can jump out of the window. You'll never make it to the ground alive.[/p] [p]You shuffle back across the floor, trying to think of a plan. As you poke around in the junk, you spot a tall, clear box at the far end of the attic. There appears to be something black in it. And leaning against it is a broom.[/p] [p]Could that be the witch's broom – the one on the scavenger hunt list? You hurry over to investigate.[/p] [p]“Help me!” a shrill voice cries as you reach for the broom.[/p] [p]The voice is coming from the box! There's a woman trapped inside![/p] [p]Her face is lined with deep wrinkles. Her long, knotted gray hair flows over a black dress.[/p] [p]“Wow!” You gasp.[/p] [p]The woman stares at you. Her green eyes seem to pierce through your flesh. “At last!” she wails. “I've been waiting two hundred years for you!”[/p]

[p]“Leave me alone, kid!” you squeak. You crawl out of the drawer and swoop over to the letters. You've decided to spell out your name. That way Marcie will know the bat is really you.[/p] [p]You start searching through the pile of letters. You hear Darryl moving toward you. You search faster. Darryl's toddling closer. But he's so excited that he falls down. You've found the first letter of your first name. Quickly, you search for the other letters.[/p] [p]You've just finished finding all the letters in your name when Darryl reaches you. You look up to see him towering over you. He's about to lose his balance again. He reaches for a cabinet to steady himself.[/p] [p]“Be careful!” you squeak. “You're going to pull that –”[/p] [p]CRASH![/p] [p]Whoops! Darryl pulled the cabinet over. Unfortunately, it was very heavy. Even more unfortunately, you were directly underneath it.[/p] [p]Too bad. Now you won't even get to be on TV – unless they come up with a show called “Flat Pet Tricks.”[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]The next morning you wake up as a kid again. You're pretty sure you can avoid being toasted if you stay out of the sun as much as possible and really cover up. To be safe, you wear your hat, sunglasses, muffler, and gloves.[/p] [p]“Why are you dressed like that?” Marcie asks when you meet your friends at the mall. She and the others laugh.[/p] [p]“Maybe we were wrong about you,” Martin teases. “Maybe you're too weird for the Horror Club.”[/p] [p]“Why are you wearing all those clothes?” Marcie asks again.[/p] [p]You'd better rethink this. You'd hate to lose the only friends you have. “My mom,” you say, rolling your eyes. “I'm getting a cold and this is what she did to me.”[/p] [p]“My mom's the same way,” Lara agrees sympathetically.[/p] [p]You'll have to wait for a better time to tell them the truth. “So what's the plan?” you ask.[/p] [p]“Let's check out the new science store,” Lara suggests.[/p] [p]“I'd rather go to the movies,” Martin says. “[em]Dracula[/em] is about to start.”[/p] [p]“Let's let the newest member of the Horror Club decide,” Marcie says, turning to you.[/p] [p][em]It's up to you now.[/em][/p]

If you'd rather see Dracula

p.text: [p]You've decided to wait for the monster's help.[/p] [p]“How do you like our library?” the blue head asks.[/p] [p]“It's very nice,” you say. “Those are cool-looking monster books. But I [em]really[/em] need to go back home.”[/p] [p]“All in good time,” the red head rumbles. “Can you read?”[/p] [p]“Well, of course I can,” you answer. You wonder if the monster is going to write down directions for you.[/p] [p]“Great!” the red head cries. “We love being read to. Our librarian was a good reader, until she became a Swamp Thing snack. After you read our favorite stories to us, we'll show you how to go home.”[/p] [p]“If you won't,” the blue head adds, leering at you with its enormous yellow eye, “we'll eat you. Are you ready?”[/p] [p]You don't have much choice. But how hard could it be to read a couple of stories? The monster leads you into the next room.[/p] [p]“Which story should I read?” you ask.[/p] [p]“All of them,” insists the blue head. The monster points to the shelves. You can see that they contain thousands of books. “The rest are in the basement,” the red head adds.[/p] [p]Too bad – it looks as if you're going to be busy for a while. If you ever want to get home, you better learn to speed-read![/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You have to break your fall! You reach out your arms and drag your fingers along the wall of the crevice. It slows you down a bit. Then the light begins to change, and you don't have to fight so hard to slow your descent. By the time you reach the bottom, you're almost floating. You land gently on a bed of moss.[/p] [p]You scan your new surroundings. You seem to be in a swamp. A swamp full of strange, twisted trees, and flitting insects. A smell of decay overwhelms you and mournful cries fill the air. You're overcome by a feeling of dread.[/p] [p]You want to get out of this creepy place – quick![/p] [p]You run along a river bank, hoping it will lead somewhere. But before you have gone far, you come to a broken sign pointing in two directions. One part of the sign points across the river: TO THE CRYPT. The other part points to the path, but it is so old and weathered that it has no words left on it at all. Which way should you go?[/p]

p.text: [p]“Please,” you beg. “It's important. We ve got to stop meeting in the mansion.”[/p] [p]“No way,” Martin says. “If you don't like it here, go form your own club.”[/p] [p]“But –” you start to protest. But at that moment Professor Krupnik's ghostly voice fills the room. “YOU FAILED!” it moans. “NOW I MUST TAKE MATTERS INTO MY OWN HANDS!”[/p] [p]The room suddenly fills with smoke and bright flashes of light. Your friends start to scream.[/p] [p]“Wait –” you cry. But your voice comes out as a high-pitched squeak. In horror, you realize it's too late. You've turned back into a bat. You glance around to see three other bats flying around the living room in panic.[/p] [p]“Help!” Lara squeaks in her bat voice. “What's happened?”[/p] [p]“We've all been turned into bats,” you say sadly.[/p] [p]Too bad! You made the wrong choice. But at least you'll have someone to hang around with.[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]Your bat's stomach insists moths are delicious. Following the sonar, you swoop into the tree and grab the insect in your jaws. Its body feels soft and powdery, and the bitter flavor makes you want to hurl. But you're starving. Gagging, you swallow. Then you zoom after another moth.[/p] [p]When you've finished your mothy meal, you fly straight for the graveyard and the Krupnik Crypt, landing on the top of the open door.[/p] [p]The door is bigger than you remembered. But then, you're a lot smaller. You drop to the ground and try pushing against it. It doesn't move. Even an inch. You fly into it, but all that happens is you bruise your wings.[/p] [p]What will you do? As a bat, you're too weak to close the door. When you're a human, you can't leave the house. Then you think of your Horror Club team. Maybe you can get them to help you.[/p] [p]But who should you ask first? Martin's the strongest, Lara's the friendliest, but Marcie seems the bravest.[/p] [p]Quick – decide who to visit and fly to their house![/p]
